answers.answer: The likelihood of this being secondary to ischemic heart disease is unlikely but is also dependent on your risk factors for heart disease, that is your age, presence of diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, or pre-existing heart disease. Now you could have a heart rhythm, disorder, such as a tachycardia, which could be diagnosed with the use of a  Holter monitor. But these arrhythmias can also occur in the setting of lung disease, so if you have symptoms or signs of pulmonary problems such as an infection then you should have that addressed first ( via antibiotics etc) and then if the arrhythmia recurs, ask for a Holter monitor so the diagnosis can be narrowed.

My heart raced and pounded for probably 6 yrs (off & on).  When I would wake from a nap or from a nights sleep, my heart would start pounding.  I had a SVT attack this yr.  I had every kind of test imaginable done on my heart and all came back normal.  My gp did further checking on my thyroid, which has been on the low side for yrs.  But because it was within normal limits, never bothered to check further.  Well after further checking, I have autoimmune thyroiditis.  I have been bothered with heart palpitations, heart pounding, heart racing, great fatigue, etc.for about 6 yrs.    I am on a thyroid medication now and seem to be getting better.  If you let thyroid problems go too long, it can cause heart problems.  It might be somewhere to start.  From what I understand, your thyroid is the BOSS.  It controls everything!!!  It even controls your body temp.   Good Luck!
